title: Why do ADC's believe their role is so hard?
body:
I think Sky Williams managed to prove this pretty conclusively. ADC is just NOT that hard at all to play. Its a role that has some of the best objective damage in the game, some of the best items in the game and no other role has somebody in lane SPECIFICALLY there to make sure you don't die. Essentially you are just being babied for the first 10-15 minutes of the game.

So why are most AD Carry Mains I have observed, so arrogant?

replies.body:
I think it's because there's very little room for error as ADC. If you step out of position, you just die instantly and contribute nothing to a fight. Roles that are more CD reliant like tanks, mages, and supports can all at least fire off a solid ability rotation before they get blown up. 

ADCs end up blaming team and such because they are so reliant on their team, and because they are under so much pressure not to make ANY mistakes in the late game (if your adc dies for no reason late game, you lose the teamfight guaranteed). At least, that's my analysis as a support main.

It's like playing I Wanna Be The Guy.

Everything is out to kill you and you die instantly if you make a mistake.

Pretty much. ADC becomes the most important role in really close games and the deciding factor, which makes me hate playing adc because it's too high pressure.

This is why I just play Fizz instead :3

so this is what it's like to be memed

> This is why I just play Fizz instead :3

http://img.pandawhale.com/57120-walter-white-wink-gif-kZiy.gif
So these are the type of post Rioters respond to? Yet, you guys ignore all of the countless posts regarding the broken Ranked and Matchmaking System? League of Legends is such a joke.

They are people and players just like you and me. They can respond to whatever they want.  A good reason why they dont respond to official threads is because they are either 1.) Not on the team in charge of it(the most likely reason, I see people bitching about gameplay and balance issues to visual and sound effects or lore people like they control it...) or 2.) They can't say anything that isn't concrete or the back lash will be even bigger.  If you want to know what a joke is, I suggest you look in the mirror.

Basically #1. I work on the Release team, I do QA. The things that I work on are of little interest to most players, so I just hop on to chat about random stuff and maybe find some people to play with.

If anyone has any questions about how hotfixes or patches get from our internal stuffs to your computer, I can answer those!

Usually no one cares about the work that I do until something goes wrong :(
how stressful was the hotfix for the Dark Star Thresh bug?

It was pretty rough.

I wasn't personally working on it, but one of the guys on my team was working all weekend to get it ready. Then we had some problems with our patching tool on Monday that prevented us from hotfixing it out at the planned 1:00am time, so he ended up triaging the issue until like, 4:00am. Eventually they had to call it and we were forced to push it out on Tuesday morning instead :(

We generally do everything we can to get fixes out as quickly and safely as possible, so it's a super bummer when stuff goes wrong that loses that much time (12 hours is a big loss in our book).

As a programmer lead, I feel your pain >_<.  I need to get my team to get in as many fixes as possible before the release freeze on Midnight Friday.  Yet at least I never have a bunch of idiots yelling at me about the... art or something I have no control over.  *Eyes a certain other reply*.  I can only imagine.  

Keep up the good work and know that some of us, while sometimes frustrated at certain aspects/decisions of Riot with League of Legends, doesn't blame every single Rioter out there.  Plenty of unsung heroes out there.  So on behalf of those players, Thanks. :-)

~David
{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}}

Suddenly, Koalifier becomes my favorite Rioter.
Take that @Cactopus

what has been the worst, but neccisary hotfix you've worked on? 
in terms of "overpowered/underpowered"  and in terms of "if this champ is picked the game crashes"
im gonna take a guess, and say Leblanc was a harsh one, and the Tiamat drop bug that would crash games.

overpowered/underpowered: {{champion:72}} 

if this champ is picked the game crashes: Okay, this isn't really a horrible bug, but I found it to be really absurd. Basically, there was once a bug where clicking thresh lantern or clicking to start channeling on a Dominion turret while simultaneously disconnecting would cause the server to crash, kicking all 10 players out of the game. It was just so absurd when we figured out what was happening :/

The instant recall bug was really memorable too: http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/riot-games/editorial/total-recall-or-time-we-disabled-ranked

There was also the bug where Corki's W was doing insane damage at rank 1, like 300 damage or something like that. It happened before the update last fall. That one was interesting because we started getting reports of it from Australia really early on, so we ended up disabling him and getting the fix out pretty quickly.
What was the funniest bug you had to fix?
Hmm, since I mostly work with super urgent Live bugs, I don't get to fix many funny ones. Hmmm... probably this one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Da_-nEnkT0

Not sure how 'urgent' this is, but it certainly is interesting.
https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/4oeww3/new_mechanic_how_to_do_invisible_skills_ft_akali/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NR_xUq2EXgk
Oh yeah this one was super funny! It actually worked with other champions too, so that was pretty cool. (although it was way harder to pull of on Tham)
that was a beautiful story. I cannot believe how stressful that was.
So little room for error you have 4 other players basically holding your hand through the game.

> [{quoted}](name=MetalGearTeemu,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=fexZU83v,comment-id=0008000a,timestamp=2016-06-23T20:25:06.946+0000)
>
> So little room for error you have 4 other players basically holding your hand through the game.

You've never solo queued as an ADC have you?

I would agree with you, as a support main as well. However there are some ADC's that are less reliant on their team, {{champion:15}} for example, who is able to block enemy abilities and use her ult to get out of danger. But ADC's generally have better items nowadays to cope with the pressures of being an ADC. As a support main, you know, there is nothing more annoying then an over-agressive ADC at the start of the game who doesn't know the champion you are playing very well and insists on trying to rush for kills and ends up feeding because you do not have the needed power to ensure they are successful yet. I think that is one of the reasons {{champion:43}} was become popular again (I picked her up way before her recent popularity spike). She provides power straight away and can get her shield at level two, instantly providing powerful poke and powerful utility with her ultimate.

I just pray to the Riot lords that she does not get nerfed or even worse "reworked" because of her recent increase in popularity. She's about the only champ in League I really like because of the access to her ult at level one.

Im a very aggressive adc main in plat. That said, I understand my champion, and most meta supports. Right now in the current meta, I can't think of a single support that can't properly support an early aggressive ADC. 

During champ select, AND at the start of the game I make sure to let my support know that I play very aggressive, because I know properly supporting that aggression requires starting with a different skill than if I were playing passive. The problem arises when, despite me saying that I'm going to be aggressive, the support only levels the passive skill.

For example: Soraka:W>Q>E for aggressive vs Q>W>E for passive. Morgana: Q or E for aggressive (depending on enemy bot lane) Q and W for passive lane. Janna? Please dont take W in the first 2 levels. Put a shield on me, and tornado peel if I get in trouble. 

I mean personally, I prefer a soraka played at her relatively low skill ceiling over a thresh played at a mediocre level. With raka staying out of danger while healing, slowing, and silencing enemies, I feel as though I'm in a 1v2 except with greatly increased health. With good ADC mechanics its stupid easy to get a double kill level 2 with a well played soraka.

TLDR: Sorry, I kinda went off on a tangent, but my point is that supporting an adc that plays aggressive early on doesn't need a support with a lot of damage. If you can heal, peel, shield, or in any other way help me avoid death, I can do the damage needed.
Your every junglers, mid laners, and top laners with TP wet dream

I understand that but the amount of time a {{champion:67}} or {{champion:236}} has spoken to me like utter s**t, for absolutely no reason. Because I play {{champion:43}} as a main and they want a tank for some reason. I do know what Karma does and does not counter, she is my main. Or because I do not buy {{item:2049}} as my first time when I have already fed them a double kill in bot lane. I usually will get a {{item:2043}} to compensate for the small lack of vision because I want to actually have better mana when I get back into lane.
K... i mean id get boots or the upgraded spellthief item or something, but if your first back you get like a chalice?  Not that they should flame you but they're right to be critical

Chalice is an amazing item for the laning phase, though. It's an unusual first buy because Sightstone and increased gold income are so important, but if you have the gold for Chalice it gives 3x as much additional mana as upgrading to Frostfang does, or health regen if the lane is rough. 

Chalice is at its best in a laning situation, to the point where I'd say it is the only acceptable alternative to rushing Sightstone/Frostfang. Criticism from the ADC really isn't warranted as long as delaying your vision control is acceptable in a particular game.
It's because of the mentality that they have to solo carry the game so they think they're the VIP.

In terms of sheer mechanical demand within a role, ADC is probaby near the top just due to the demand that high attack speed kiting demands. Trying to kite with Kalista after you hit 2.0 attack speed is kind of brutal on your CPS, and even the most minimal mistake means death. At least as a tank you can make a mistake and probably survive because you can take that amount of damage. 

Plus, ADCs always have champions like {{champion:238}}  and {{champion:7}}  and {{champion:64}}  and  {{champion:121}}  and  {{champion:107}}   who are looking to typically kill your first, so it's kind of stressful having that type of pressure when you know if they touch you, you die instantly, even if you don't necessarily do anything obviously wrong. Mistakes that lead to death could be just being slightly too far away from your support or being slightly too far forward where any other role would be fine being positioned.

Based on damage output, ADC is usually among the top tier damage threats on a team, and if you die, you can singlehandedly concede any team fight because you're not there. That's a big amount of pressure to carry around. I've personally played very nervously in fights because I know if I die, my team will very likely lose the fight, and it'd be mostly my fault. 

Not justifying toxicity; that's not a valid reason to be toxic. Also odds are high it's just the person and not the role. Stereotypes aside, most ADCs aren't dicks. They're just in a high pressure situation, just like everyone in a game of LoL.

> somebody in lane SPECIFICALLY there to make sure you don't die

Lol, I've been playing support wrong, my goal is always specifically to make sure the enemy ADC does die. {{champion:143}} FTW
"death is best CC " philosophy representing here

As an ADC main, the role is probably hardest to position with (imo) and heavily team reliant, so when people mess up they like to act arrogant, because technically speaking they are the most important role. I don't know what else to tell you.

EDIT: That's interesting. I didn't expect downvotes for saying why ADC's act arrogant.

Well thank you for your insight but some ADC's just come into the game toxic, even some Gold or Higher ADC's, I have seen treating their supports like trash. I remember a Janna accidentally killed one minion with her tornado and this Vayne instantly AFK'd and called her a "shitty support" and the worst player in League.

I hate that everyone uses this argument that "no other role has someone their to babysit them the whole game". Yes, that's true, but it doesn't matter. The enemy has someone there doing the exact same thing. If a mid laner had a duo que that went mid with them every game as thresh to make sure they won, and the enemy didn't have that then that would make it easy, but both you and enemy having that role there for you makes it really even. {{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}}

Because a light breeze kills us at all stages of the game and we are responsible for our own survival the majority of the game because solo que players don't usually realize that we have a giant bullseye on our backs as our 4 pals dive in to every team fight. That was a long a long run on sentence. #Feelsbadman.

I would have agreed with this... butttttttttttttttttttttt......{{item:3153}} {{item:3812}} {{item:3508}} {{item:3022}} {{item:3036}} {{item:3094}} {{item:3046}} {{item:3124}} {{item:3085}}{{item:3072}}   now if you had said mages who didn't get an update, I would have agreed because...{{item:3027}} {{item:3157}}{{item:3146}}   I think I rest my case.

You realize ADCs don't start with those items right? But yeah an ADC with 10 items will likely be able to fend for himself.

I'm confused by your post.

many factors come to mind, the first: for being the best dmg on a team with the best items you're target number one.

I wouldn't say it's the hardest to play but there's many things to keep in check while playing adc.

You think it's easy to play with another champion in lane that supposedly is there to protect you, well... some of the so called supports have no intention of doing so, some of them don't even have the tools to keep you safe...

You need to work in tandem with your lane partner too, if he's aggressive you need to be a bit aggressive too and try not to miss cs and try to ward what he won't be warding. If he's more passive then you need to keep yourself safe and try to cs as much as you can while trading from time to time.

Mid and top lanes deal with 1 champion in their lanes, adcs have to deal with 3... you also should be looking at your mana bar and at your support's mana bar, gotta make sure that when you go in he can follow, or if he goes in you need to make it worth by dealing as much dmg as possible.

A lot of lane related stuff is also a problem when you throw two people in a lane, if you and your support don't have the same mindset, bad things happen. For example if you wanna freeze lane and your support simply doesn't agrees, he'll push and there's not much you can do about it but ask as politely as possible.

On a teamfight you kinda need protection since you're the most valuable target (or one of them at least, even if behind) if everyone is a diver... adcs have an awful bad time.

I think Sky Williams managed to prove this pretty conclusively.
Sky Williams talks and talks and talks until u think he is right, but if u think about his words, they are full of sht. (not always, but he is one of the greatest shittalkers on earth)

ADC is just NOT that hard at all to play.
That's because League of legends is not hard to play in general.

Its a role that has some of the best objective damage in the game
You still need your team to prepare for objectives

some of the best items
only if you get farm, feed or lategame, otherwise items are meaningless. And still, they can get one shotted by any mediocre assassin

and no other role has somebody in lane SPECIFICALLY there to make sure you don't die.
in most games i have to play adc I get a somebody that gives no shit about me dying, or wards, or objectives...

Essentially you are just being babied for the first 10-15 minutes of the game.
You should be, in many games you are not.

So why are most AD Carry Mains I have observed, so arrogant?
That's your interpretation. I think most of them are dissatisfied, because there is no other role that depends so much on the team game. All strengths you mentioned are only take affect, if your teammembers play for you. In my opinion, the better support wins the botlane, not the better adc. With any other role you are flexible, you can play around counters or ganks. The succes of an adc heavily depends on the beahviour of his teammates. Your main job as adc is to get farm and objectives. You can only archieve these goals if your team/support helps you to accomplish them. With other words: Adc is the most sensitive role in the game.
Or maybe toxicity is dependent on the player and not the specific role...

bullshit. 

Difficulty is simply a case of:
1. how many decisions you need to make
1.5. how many decisions do you have the freedom of making?
2. how much are your actions contested (skill=checked) by opposing players?
3. how much of the skill check is in favor of your opponent? 
4. what is the degree of perfection in execution required of you?

(2) and (3) are pretty high up, for ADCs, and (4) if you want to play decently is also quite high.
as an ADC, (1) is really lacking. 

(1) lacking + 2,3,4 at high levels translates to stress and feeling of lacking agency.

Heres my view as a diamond mid/jg main

I think there are different TYPES of hard. Jungling isn't that much about mechanics, it's more about strategy and knowledge. Adc is hard in terms of mechanics

You can't really out-think your opponent as an adc. You pretty much rely on raw mechanics for most of the game which makes it the hardest mechanical role (tied with mid imo) while jungle is the hardest knowledge role (support close behind)

I think it's more like: mid is bursty mechanics and aiming. Most of the time you are freefarming, except when you get all in'ed or you are all in'ing. So you need alot of APM when you do fight, but most of the time you can sit back (on most mids). ADC requires continuously high mechanics and you are clicking around all the time, even just to farm.

Sadly i found this post pretty late but maybe u will read it: 
Mid is by far the most stressful lane in the game. 
You are in danger of getting ganked from basically every corner. Now with the vision changes you rely heavily on your teammates to ping and ward properly (roaming support for example). The whole laning phase is kinda like chess. You try to punish every mistake the enemy makes like overstepping, trying to harass you outpositioned, counter harass etc. 
Jungler expects you to help him out or follow up all the time when something around u happens, teammates in general want you to roam especially on champs like LB or Zed.
Also if you lose your lane and fall behind your team is pretty much fucked.
mid and jungle are the hardest because you have to think the most.
